parts: Discuss the attached PDF file and analyze the implications of the ideas therein on the job market, how our education curriculum should be structured, and what existing workers should do to future-proof their careers and skills
Make sure to include citeturn0file0 in your response to cite this file.

Age of the Agent Orchestrator
Shyamal Hitesh Anadkat
Applied AI @ OpenAI
May 18, 2025
Over the past couple of years at OpenAI, many friends and family have often asked me 
what the world might look like when AI and agents can do "everything". it's a question 
we’re still collectively wrestling with. while that's not happening anytime soon, 
capabilities are advancing quickly enough that it’s worth thinking a step ahead.
One frame that I find useful is to ask what becomes scarce. Markets tend to organize 
around whatever is in short supply.
When personal computers and then the internet showed up, the scarce thing became 
knowing how to write software. if you knew how to program, you could create a 
tremendous amount of value relative to almost anyone else. When Excel showed up, 
the scarce thing for a while was knowing how to use it - you could model and 
understand a business better than the people still doing math on paper.
Once you can reliably put a spreadsheet, a legal brief, a codebase, a marketing plan, a 
budget, or whatever else into a loop with a capable model - ask it to do the work, check 
the work, improve the work, and repeat - the scarce thing is no longer "who knows 
how to do that task by hand". The scarce thing becomes "who can orchestrate 
resources well" - compute, capital, access to data, and human/expert judgment.
Here are three consequences I see if we get to that world:
Expertise gets democratized.
The premium shifts from "I know the tax code" to "I can design the loop that gets 
the right answer and runs cheaply".

Right now, you hire an expert to do your taxes because the space of possible mistakes is 
large and the cost of being wrong is high. If you can build (or rent) an agent that can do a 
competent job of your taxes, ask for feedback, double-check edge cases, and improve 
over time, then the gatekeeping function of the expert goes away. There will still be 
experts - we will need people to provide judgment, to set the high-level strategy, to 
handle the weird cases - but the leverage point moves. Knowing the details of the tax 
code will be less valuable than knowing how to set up an autonomous workflow that 
produces a correct return, flags the ambiguous parts for a human to look at, and costs 
$0.05 in compute instead of $5. This is great news for a lot of people.
The knowledge that used to require years of schooling and apprenticeships will be 
accessible to anyone who can chat, call an API, and structure a loop. it's also going to 
be uncomfortable for people whose status is tied up in being the only ones who can do
something. If you're training for a career because you believe the information is 
scarce, it's worth asking yourself what happens when it's not. If you're training to be 
the person who can take all of the cheap information and turn it into a valuable 
outcome, you're on firmer ground.
Resource optimization matters a lot more.
We are going to have to get very good at assigning FLOPs/compute, liquidity, lab 
time, human review, etc., to autonomous workflows/agents. This is a new job.
Today, if you want to do a big marketing analysis, you send it to your analyst and she 
tells you it'll be done in two weeks. She has some rough mental model of her own time 
and the other things on her plate. In a world where you can spin up 10k agents to do 10k 
analyses, your bottlenecks become very different. Your compute cluster is finite. Your 
budget is finite. The number of hours your expert reviewers have is finite. If you spray 
tasks everywhere without thinking, you'll hit resource limits fast. The teams that know 
how to prioritize which agent gets which compute, when to spend $10 on more compute 
versus when to ask a human for 5 minutes of feedback, how to queue up a million tasks 
overnight when energy is cheap, how to take advantage of low-liquidity windows, and so 
on, are going to have a big advantage.
Startups have always had to allocate capital carefully. In this new regime, you have to 
allocate compute carefully too. It's not a "set it and forget it" situation - models will get 
better, costs will go down, new tasks will appear. you will need people whose job is 
literally to orchestrate fleets of AI agents and the scarce resources they need. Think of it 
like an air traffic controller or "orchestrator" for agents. the very best companies already 
do some of this. They optimize cloud spend, they schedule jobs, they think about 
capital efficiency. But most companies are extremely wasteful with both human and 
machine time. That won't be sustainable when the throughput of work an organization 
can do is limited by its ability to coordinate.

Literacy in managing agents becomes the new Excel.
Knowing how to break down a task, set a reward, audit a run is going to be a 
baseline skill.
Companies that run lots of agent A/B tests and bake that into their culture will 
compound faster than the ones that try to bolt AI onto old workflows and drown in 
complexity. When Excel showed up, there was a window of time where if you knew how 
to use it, you were special. Then it became table stakes - if you worked in finance and 
didn't know how to use a spreadsheet, you were unemployable. The same thing is going 
to happen with managing AI agents. being able to write a decent prompt, set up a 
feedback loop, monitor the outputs, tweak the reward function, and run an experiment 
to see if version A or version B of your agent loop works better will be as expected as 
knowing how to make a pivot table. This isn't "prompt engineering" in the meme sense. 
it's product management for agents -- thinking about edge cases, it's deciding when to

let the agent run versus when to stop and ask a human, it's noticing when the agent is 
optimizing the wrong thing because you gave it the wrong reward.
If you build a culture where it's normal for someone in customer support to spin up an 
agent to handle a new type of ticket, run an A/B test to see if it works, and ship it without 
waiting for approval from the AI team, you will move much faster than a company that 
treats AI as a centralized function that has to be integrated slowly into legacy processes. 
The companies that try to bolt AI onto their old workflows are going to drown. They will 
create complexity, have shadow processes, and end up with humans checking AI 
checking humans. The companies that are willing to reimagine their workflows around 
agents, to run lots of experiments, to build internal tooling for agent management, are 
going to compound. Culture eats strategy. If you don't create an environment where 
people are comfortable delegating to machines, measuring the outcomes, and 
iterating, you'll miss out on a huge amount of leverage.
One of the most satisfying frameworks I’ve found for understanding AI progress is 
the METR curve, which measures AI performance based on the length of tasks AI 
agents can complete.

METR
"Extrapolating this trend predicts that, in under a decade, we will see AI agents that 
can independently complete a large fraction of software tasks that currently take 
humans days or weeks."
None of this happens overnight. The models still make mistakes. The tooling for 
managing agents is immature. the best practices for resource orchestration are not 
obvious yet. We don't have a lot of people who are great at this new job.
but if you believe that the capability curves are going to keep going up, you should get 
ready for the shift in scarcity. Start learning how to design loops. Start instrumenting 
your compute spend. Start hiring people who are excited to be air traffic controllers 
for AI. start teaching your team how to set up and audit agent workflows.
As always, the most important thing is to build something that users want. In a world 
where your marginal cost of expertise/knowledge goes to zero, your ability to turn 
cheap intelligence and expensive resources into valuable products is what will 
matter. i'm very excited to see the new companies, the new tools, and the new jobs that 
come out of this.
Welcome to the Age of the Agent Orchestrator!

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the implications of ideas in a PDF. I think I can analyze the content using internal knowledge, though I could browse for external context like job trends or curriculum changes. But it's not completely necessary, since we're focused on the PDF analysis. If relevant data is available internally, I can use that instead of browsing. Of course, I can still check external sources to support claims if I think it's useful!

The user's question about AI adoption and the job market might benefit from up-to-date data. While I could rely on internal analysis, it feels safe to look for recent labor market reports, like the World Economic Forum’s "Future of Jobs Report 2024" or McKinsey’s 2023 analysis on AI jobs. This sort of external data could strengthen the answer. I'll search for up-to-date resources before providing a complete response.

search_queries.q: World Economic Forum Future of Jobs 2024 report AI adoption impact on skills
McKinsey 2023 Generative AI workers skills demand report

entries.title: Davos: AI 'FOBO' and How a CEO Ditched the Meeting Room for the Ski Slope - Business Insider
entries.snippet: Total lines: 43

thoughts.content: The user's question about AI adoption in the job market might benefit from more up-to-date labor data. While I can rely on general analysis, it could be helpful to look for recent reports, like the World Economic Forum's 2024 “Future of Jobs” or McKinsey's 2023 study on AI and jobs. This might add more context and support to my thoughts, so I plan to search for relevant external resources to make the response stronger.

The shift towards AI orchestration means new roles like AI resource optimizer and agent product manager will emerge, while middle-skill tasks are replaced. High-level judgment remains crucial. According to reports, a significant percentage of skills and tasks will be automated in the coming years. In education, AI literacy should become a baseline startup skill, with an emphasis on systems thinking, resource allocation, and soft skills like ethics and creativity. Lifelong learning, interdisciplinary approaches, and AI-focused labs should be introduced earlier in the curriculum.

To stay relevant, workers should adopt a growth mindset and focus on AI literacy. They should learn prompt engineering, break tasks into loops to delegate to AI, and upskill with open-source frameworks like LangChain. Specializing in domain-specific judgment and building meta-skills such as creative problem-solving and data storytelling is essential. Practicing resource optimization, especially for cloud and devops, will also be crucial. Networking through continuous learning programs and institutional support for reskilling will help transition into future roles. Strategic actions can be outlined in a detailed narrative with citations and supporting data from referenced content.

parts:
### Executive Summary Shyamal Anadkat’s essay *Age of the Agent Orchestrator* argues that, once most routine knowledge-work can be put “in a loop” with capable AI agents, **scarcity shifts from *knowing how to do a task* to *knowing how to design, resource and supervise the agentic workflow***citeturn0file0. This has three first-order consequences: | Consequence (from the paper) | Deeper labour-market meaning | |---|---| | **Expertise is democratised** | Cognitive entry barriers fall; value migrates from possession of facts to orchestration of processes. | | **Resource-optimisation becomes central** | A new managerial layer emerges that allocates compute, data, capital and human review. | | **Agent-literacy becomes the new Excel** | Basic employability now requires the ability to break work into loops, set rewards, audit and A/B test agents. | Below I unpack what this means for (1) the job market, (2) how we structure curricula, and (3) what today’s workers should do. --- ## 1 | Implications for the Job Market 1. **New high-leverage roles appear** * *Agent/Resource Orchestrator* (digital “air-traffic controller”) to allocate FLOPs, budget and expert review slotsciteturn0file0. * *Agent Product Manager*—blending prompt design, reward shaping, risk and UX. * *AI Cost Engineer / FinOps-for-AI* to optimise cluster utilisation and carbon-aware scheduling. 2. **Middle-skill knowledge jobs compress** Generative AI can already automate activities that occupy **60–70 % of employee time** and may halve the timeline for 50 % automation to the 2030-2060 windowciteturn3view0. McKinsey’s 2024 modelling shows **up to 30 % of hours in the US & EU automated by 2030**, requiring ~12 million occupational transitions in each regionciteturn4view0. 3. **Polarisation but not uniform decline** * Demand rises for STEM, data, healthcare and roles requiring **high-stakes judgment, domain context or physical presence**. * Routine office support, entry-level analysis and repetitive customer service shrink first. 4. **Acceleration of “FOBO” dynamics** CEOs now openly predict they will be the last to manage purely human workforces, fuelling “fear of becoming obsolete” among white-collar staffciteturn6view0. 5. **Skill half-life shortens** The WEF finds **~39 % of current skillsets will be obsolete by 2030**; yet “skill instability” is falling where firms invest in reskilling programmesciteturn5view0. LinkedIn data shows workers are **2× more likely to add AI skills than in 2018**, and hiring managers now treat AI literacy as a baselineciteturn2view0. --- ## 2 | Re-engineering the Education Curriculum | Stage | Curriculum Shifts | Pedagogical Notes | |---|---|---| | **Primary / Lower-Secondary** | Computational thinking, systems & feedback loops via block-based agents; ethics & bias games. | Make “designing a mini-agent” as common as building a science fair volcano. | | **Upper-Secondary** | Domain-integrated agent projects (history analysis bots, biology simulation loops); cost-aware cloud labs; data stewardship. | Treat compute quotas like lab reagents to teach scarcity management. | | **Tertiary & Vocational** | • Agent-orchestration studios (prompt → policy → reward → monitor).
• DevOps-for-AI & FinOps modules.
• Multi-disciplinary capstones pairing domain experts with orchestration majors. | Assessment by *live A/B tests* of student-built agents on real tasks. | | **Continuous Adult Learning** | Micro-credentials in:
• Prompt & policy design
• AI cost-optimisation
• Human-in-the-loop risk auditing
• Advanced soft-skill labs (negotiation, critical thinking, creativity). | Delivered through agent-tutors that personalise pathways and surface edge-cases for discussion. | **Why this structure?** The paper makes clear that *loop design, resource allocation and auditing* are the new “reading, writing and arithmetic”citeturn0file0. Embedding these early—and coupling them with creativity, ethics and domain depth—prevents curricula from training students for skills whose scarcity is already collapsing. --- ## 3 | Future-Proofing Strategies for Today’s Workers | Time-horizon | Concrete Actions | Rationale | |---|---|---| | **Next 90 days** | • Map your tasks into *sub-loops*; pilot delegation to ChatGPT/Copilot.
• Take an *AI-FinOps* micro-course; instrument your cloud spending. | Builds intuition for orchestration economics and reveals quick wins. | | **6-12 months** | • Earn a recognised *Agent-PM* or *Prompt-Design* certificate.
• Ship a public portfolio (GitHub, Kaggle, Medium posts) showing loop-design, reward tuning, A/B experiments. | Signalling—hiring managers now filter on AI-literacyciteturn2view0. | | **Ongoing (annual)** | • Rotate into roles that mix **domain judgement + AI supervision** (e.g., tax strategist overseeing auto-prep pipelines).
• Cultivate uniquely human meta-skills—storytelling, negotiation, interdisciplinary synthesis. | Human judgment remains the costly, scarce check-point in agent loopsciteturn0file0. | **Mindset shifts** 1. **From Operator → Orchestrator**: stop perfecting manual execution; perfect the loop that executes. 2. **From Tool-User → Cost-Manager**: treat FLOPs, latency and reviewer-minutes as you would dollars. 3. **From Periodic Training → Continuous Micro-upskilling**: accept 3-to-5-year skill half-lives; schedule learning like exercise. --- ### Closing Thought The METR curve reproduced on page 5 of the essay shows task length capacity **doubling roughly every seven months**citeturn0file0. When marginal expertise cost trends toward zero, *scarce coordination capacity* becomes the growth bottleneck. Individuals, educators and policy-makers that orient themselves around **agent orchestration, resource optimisation and irreplaceably human judgment** will capture the new surplus—everyone else risks FOBO becoming reality.
